readingAnalyses.title: Tonghak Uprisings
readingAnalyses.author: Ch'oe Cheu, Ch'oe Sihyong
readingAnalyses.summary: Three foundational Tonghak texts reveal the religious ideology that inspired Korea's greatest peasant uprising. Ch'oe Cheu's 'On Spreading Virtue' (1861) describes his mystical revelation and founding of Eastern Learning as a response to the Western threat. 'On Learning Truth' (1861) elaborates Tonghak theology, positioning it as distinct from yet comparable to Christianity. Ch'oe Sihyong's 'On Practicing Truth at Home' (1888) provides practical moral guidance for common believers. Together these texts show how Tonghak combined Confucian ethics, Buddhist cosmology, Daoist naturalism, and indigenous Korean shamanism into a syncretic religion with revolutionary social implications.

keyQuotes.quote: My mind is your mind. How could men know it? They may know Heaven and earth, but they know not the spirit. Yet I am the spirit. Now you shall attain this eternal truth, cultivate it, write it, and teach it to all people.

In April 1860 the whole world was in turmoil, and the hearts of the people turned evil. And a strange rumor spread in the world, saying: 'The Westerners cultivated high ethics, and there is nothing they cannot do...'
Human beings are heaven (in nae ch'on) and all are equal; there are no differences among humans, so distinctions of high and low violate God's will.
I was born in the East and received the truth in the East. Therefore, the Way is the Heavenly Way and the doctrine is the Eastern Learning.
Treat all persons at home as God. Do filial duty to your parents with all your strength... Regard your servants as your own children, love even animals.

thematicExamples: Ch'oe Cheu's revelation parallels Hong Xiuquan's visions - both claimed divine contact during illness, but Ch'oe explicitly positioned his teaching as 'Eastern' alternative to Western Christianity
The doctrine 'in nae ch'on' (human beings are heaven) provided theological basis for social equality that appealed to peasants suffering under yangban oppression
Ch'oe Sihyong's practical advice (treat servants as children, love animals, don't cut young trees) shows how Tonghak offered moral framework for daily life, not just political resistance
realLifeConnections: Tonghak's syncretic approach - combining multiple traditions into a new whole - parallels how modern religious movements adapt to their cultural contexts
The tension between 'Eastern Learning' and 'Western Learning' anticipates ongoing debates about Asian values vs. Western universalism
Ch'oe Cheu's execution (1864) for his beliefs parallels persecution of new religious movements today

readingAnalyses.title: Revolutionary Uprising of Tonghak Peasant Army
readingAnalyses.author: Various authors
readingAnalyses.summary: This secondary source provides the historical narrative of the 1894 Tonghak Peasant Revolution, tracing events from the initial uprising in Gobu county through the capture of Jeonju, the Jeonju Peace Agreement, and the final defeat at Gongju. It contextualizes the rebellion within Korea's deepening crisis: corrupt local officials, foreign economic penetration, and the weakness of the central government. Crucially, it explains how the Joseon government's request for Chinese military assistance triggered Japanese intervention and ultimately the First Sino-Japanese War - transforming a domestic uprising into an international conflict that reshaped East Asian politics.

realLifeConnections: The pattern of foreign intervention transforming domestic conflicts into international crises continues today (Syria, Yemen, Ukraine)
Peasant demands for land reform and punishment of corrupt officials remain central to agrarian movements worldwide
The tragic irony: rebels who wanted to protect Korea from foreign influence inadvertently triggered the foreign domination they feared

overallSynthesis:
The Tonghak Rebellion represents Korea's 'Taiping moment' - a religious-peasant uprising that challenged the existing order and triggered catastrophic international consequences. The primary sources from Ch'oe Cheu and Ch'oe Sihyong reveal Tonghak as a sophisticated syncretic religion responding to the crisis of the 1860s: Western imperialism, Qing weakness, and domestic corruption. Ch'oe Cheu's claim that 'my mind is your mind' and 'human beings are heaven' provided theological justification for social equality that resonated with peasants suffering under yangban oppression and corrupt officials.

Unlike Hong Xiuquan's Christianity-derived Taiping ideology, Tonghak explicitly positioned itself as 'Eastern Learning' - an indigenous Korean response to the Western threat. This nationalist dimension would prove crucial for Tonghak's long-term legacy, even as the 1894 uprising itself was crushed.

The secondary source reveals the tragic dynamics of 1894: local grievances against corrupt officials escalated into regional uprising; the weak Joseon government, unable to suppress the rebellion, requested Chinese assistance; Japan, determined not to let China dominate Korea, sent its own troops. The rebellion was suppressed, but Japanese and Chinese forces remained - leading directly to the First Sino-Japanese War. Japan's victory ended the tributary relationship between Korea and China that had structured East Asian international relations for centuries.

The Tonghak Rebellion thus illustrates a recurring pattern in modern East Asian history: domestic crisis invites foreign intervention, which transforms local conflicts into international wars with consequences far beyond what any participant intended. The peasants who rose up in Gobu to protest an unjust reservoir tax could not have imagined they were triggering a war that would make Japan an imperial power and set Korea on the path to colonization.
executiveSummary:
The Tonghak Rebellion (1894) was Korea's Taiping moment - a religious-peasant uprising that inadvertently triggered the First Sino-Japanese War and ended Chinese influence in Korea. Tonghak ('Eastern Learning') was a syncretic religion founded by Ch'oe Cheu in 1860, combining Confucian ethics, Buddhist-Daoist cosmology, and indigenous Korean traditions into a faith that proclaimed 'human beings are heaven' and all people are equal. This message resonated with peasants suffering under corrupt officials and foreign economic penetration.

When Tonghak-led peasants rose in Jeolla Province in 1894, the weak Joseon government requested Chinese military help. Japan, viewing Korea as vital to its security, also sent troops. Though the rebellion was suppressed, neither foreign army withdrew - and war erupted. Japan's decisive victory (1894-95) ended the Sino-Korean tributary relationship, revealed Qing military weakness, and established Japan as the dominant power in Korea. The Treaty of Shimonoseki (1895) forced China to recognize Korean 'independence' - meaning independence from China, not from Japan.

The Tonghak movement survived its military defeat. Renamed Cheondogyo ('Religion of the Heavenly Way') in 1905, it remains active in both Koreas today. Both North and South Korea claim the Tonghak heritage - the North emphasizing its anti-feudal peasant revolution, the South its proto-democratic nationalism.

keyQuestions.question: How was Tonghak similar to and different from the Taiping movement in China?
keyQuestions.basicAnswer: Both were peasant rebellions with religious leaders who claimed divine revelations. Both demanded social reform. But Tonghak was 'Eastern Learning' rejecting Christianity, while Taiping was based on Christian ideas. Taiping was much larger and nearly overthrew the Qing; Tonghak never threatened Seoul but triggered an international war.
keyQuestions.midAnswer: SIMILARITIES: Peasant base, charismatic founders with divine visions, social reform demands (land, equality), millenarian elements, brutal suppression. DIFFERENCES: (1) Tonghak EXPLICITLY rejected Western/Christian ideas; Taiping adapted them. (2) Scale: Taiping killed 20-30M; Tonghak was regional. (3) International consequences: Taiping was suppressed with Western help; Tonghak triggered Sino-Japanese War. (4) Survival: Taiping completely destroyed; Tonghak became Cheondogyo, still exists. Why did the SMALLER rebellion have LARGER international consequences?
keyQuestions.advancedAnswer: THE COMPARISON REVEALS STRUCTURAL DIFFERENCES. (1) Korea's strategic position between China and Japan made ANY crisis international. China's crisis could be contained regionally. (2) Taiping threatened the Qing; Tonghak didn't threaten Joseon — so why did Tonghak trigger war? Because the ISSUE wasn't the rebellion but KOREA ITSELF. (3) Foreign powers helped SUPPRESS Taiping because they preferred weak Qing to strong Taiping. Foreign powers USED Tonghak as excuse to intervene because they wanted Korea. (4) Ch'oe Cheu's explicit 'Eastern Learning' vs. Hong Xiuquan's Christian adaptation raises questions about how 'Western' ideas were received. Ch'oe KNEW he was creating an alternative; Hong thought he was understanding the truth. (5) Both movements show that alternatives to the existing order could be imagined — and that imagining alternatives was dangerous.

keyQuestions.question: Was Tonghak primarily anti-foreign, reformist, or revolutionary?
keyQuestions.basicAnswer: It was all three. Anti-foreign: founded to counter Western Learning and demanded expulsion of foreign barbarians. Reformist: the Jeonju Peace Agreement showed willingness to work within the system. Revolutionary: 'Human beings are heaven' challenged the entire yangban class system.
keyQuestions.midAnswer: All three elements were in TENSION, not harmony. (1) ANTI-FOREIGN: Founded explicitly against 'Western Learning,' rebels demanded expulsion of Japanese/Western barbarians. (2) REFORMIST: Jeonju Peace Agreement shows willingness to work within system; demands focused on corrupt officials, NOT overthrowing monarchy. (3) REVOLUTIONARY: 'In nae ch'on' (human beings are heaven) challenged the ENTIRE yangban hierarchy; peasant self-governance bureaus were proto-democratic. Foreign intervention prevented us from seeing which tendency would have dominated.
keyQuestions.advancedAnswer: THE CATEGORIES DON'T CAPTURE THE MOVEMENT. (1) 'Anti-foreign' and 'reformist' weren't opposites — Tonghak leaders wanted reform PRECISELY to strengthen Korea against foreigners. (2) 'Revolutionary' in what sense? They didn't want to overthrow the king — they wanted to purify the system. (3) The Jeonju Peace Agreement is CRUCIAL: Tonghak was willing to negotiate, establish self-governance bureaus, work within the system. The REBELLION was over by June 1894. Foreign intervention — not rebel intransigence — made peaceful resolution impossible. (4) Better frame: Tonghak was a MORAL RENEWAL movement that became political because the state was corrupt. 'In nae ch'on' isn't political ideology — it's religious teaching that has political implications. (5) The tragedy: We'll never know what Tonghak would have become because Japan made that question irrelevant.

keyQuestions.question: Why did the Tonghak Rebellion trigger war between China and Japan rather than Korean reform?
keyQuestions.basicAnswer: Korea's government was too weak to suppress the rebellion alone and asked China for help. Japan also sent troops, not wanting China to control Korea. Neither army left after the rebellion ended, and war broke out. Korea's location between two empires made its domestic crisis an international conflict.
keyQuestions.midAnswer: Korea's WEAKNESS invited intervention. (1) Government couldn't suppress rebellion alone → requested Chinese troops (under tributary obligations). (2) Japan determined not to let China dominate Korea → sent own troops. (3) Rebellion was actually SUPPRESSED by June 1894 (Jeonju Peace Agreement) — but neither foreign army withdrew. (4) Korea's strategic position meant domestic crisis became international battlefield. The pattern repeats: Korea as 'shrimp among whales.' The rebellion was the PRETEXT, not the cause.
keyQuestions.advancedAnswer: THE REBELLION WAS IRRELEVANT TO THE WAR'S CAUSES. (1) Japan had been preparing to challenge China in Korea for years — Tonghak was convenient pretext. (2) The rebellion was OVER by June 1894 (Jeonju Peace Agreement). Tonghak leaders accepted peace; it was foreign powers that rejected it. (3) China sent troops because treaty obligations required it — but also to assert traditional suzerainty. Japan sent troops to CHALLENGE that suzerainty. (4) The real question: Why was Korea the battlefield? Because Meiji Japan's entire strategic calculation required Korean 'independence' (from China, not from Japan). (5) Pattern analysis: domestic weakness → foreign intervention → international conflict → loss of sovereignty. This pattern would repeat: 1894 (Tonghak), 1904 (Russo-Japanese War fought in Korea), 1950 (Korean War). Korea's geography is destiny. (6) The deepest irony: Tonghak rebels wanted to PROTECT Korea from foreigners. Their rebellion triggered the foreign domination they feared.

keyQuestions.question: How has Tonghak been remembered differently in North and South Korea?
keyQuestions.basicAnswer: North Korea sees Tonghak as a revolutionary peasant uprising against feudalism and imperialism—a proto-communist movement. South Korea sees it as a proto-democratic movement for religious freedom and human rights. Both countries claim Tonghak's legacy. The religion survives as Cheondogyo in both Koreas.
keyQuestions.midAnswer: NORTH KOREA: Revolutionary peasant movement against feudalism and imperialism; proto-communist class struggle; anti-imperialist nationalism. Emphasizes class conflict, peasant agency, anti-Japanese resistance. SOUTH KOREA: Proto-democratic movement; religious freedom and human rights; nationalist resistance to foreign aggression. Emphasizes 'in nae ch'on' as human dignity, Jeon Bong-jun as democratic hero. Both claim legitimacy. Cheondogyo survives in BOTH Koreas — one of few organizations spanning the divide.
keyQuestions.advancedAnswer: SAME EVENT, OPPOSITE MEANINGS — which shows that historical memory is POLITICAL. (1) North emphasizes CLASS: peasants vs. yangban, proto-communist revolution. South emphasizes NATION: Koreans vs. foreigners, democratic resistance. (2) North emphasizes STRUGGLE: violent resistance is necessary. South emphasizes NEGOTIATION: Jeonju Peace Agreement shows democratic instincts. (3) Both EDIT the record: North downplays Tonghak's religious elements (incompatible with state atheism); South downplays its violent anti-yangban rhetoric (incompatible with conservative establishment). (4) Cheondogyo's survival in both Koreas is fascinating — it's one of the few institutions that spans the division. What does it mean that the SAME religion serves legitimizing functions for opposing regimes? (5) Broader lesson: History doesn't have a single meaning. Tonghak 'means' whatever contemporary politics needs it to mean. The question isn't 'what really happened?' but 'who controls the interpretation?'

connections.fromPrevious: Plate 13 examined China's Taiping Rebellion (1850-1864) - a massive religious-peasant uprising that nearly overthrew the Qing dynasty. The Tonghak Rebellion invites direct comparison: both were led by charismatic founders who claimed divine revelation, both mobilized peasants with promises of social reform, both faced brutal suppression. Key differences: Taiping was influenced by Christianity while Tonghak explicitly rejected Western Learning; Taiping was larger and came closer to success; but Tonghak's international consequences were more dramatic. The suppression of Taiping relied on Western-trained forces and created regional strongmen; Tonghak suppression required foreign intervention that triggered war. Ask students: Why did a smaller rebellion in Korea have larger international consequences than the massive Taiping uprising?
connections.toNext: Plate 15 (Joseon's Slow Evolution) examines Korea's attempts at reform in the aftermath of the Sino-Japanese War. The Gabo Reforms (1894-1896) implemented many changes the Tonghak rebels had demanded - abolition of slavery, end of status discrimination, modernization of government - but under Japanese pressure rather than Korean initiative. Students should consider: Did Tonghak 'fail' if many of its reform demands were eventually enacted? What's the difference between reform achieved through rebellion vs. reform imposed by foreign power?
connections.broaderThemes: The Tonghak Rebellion exemplifies several course themes: (1) How domestic crisis invites foreign intervention that transforms local conflicts into international wars; (2) The emergence of indigenous responses to Western imperialism that draw on traditional resources while creating something new; (3) The tension between reform and revolution - Tonghak leaders signed the Jeonju Peace Agreement hoping for reform, but foreign intervention foreclosed that possibility; (4) Korea's tragic position as battleground for larger powers - 'shrimp among whales'; (5) How historical memory serves present politics - both Koreas claim Tonghak for radically different purposes.

teachingNotes: The film 'Run High, Run Far' (Plate 16) depicts the Tonghak Rebellion - preview it here so students know to watch for key themes

Ch'oe Cheu's revelation narrative parallels Hong Xiuquan's - both sick, received divine message, founded new religion. But Ch'oe explicitly rejected Christianity; Hong adapted it. Ask students why this difference matters.
The doctrine 'in nae ch'on' (human beings are heaven) is revolutionary - it challenges the entire yangban social order. Connect to modern human rights discourse.
Jeon Bong-jun's nickname 'General Green Bean' (Nokdu Janggun) humanizes him - he was short but commanded loyalty. South Korean democracy activists adopted him as symbol.
The Jeonju Peace Agreement shows rebels weren't trying to overthrow the state - they wanted reform. Foreign intervention, not rebel intransigence, prevented peaceful resolution.
Map the cascade: local grievance (corrupt magistrate) -> regional uprising -> government weakness -> foreign intervention -> international war. This pattern recurs throughout East Asian history.
Both Koreas claim Tonghak legacy - this is a good entry point for discussing how historical memory serves present politics. Cheondogyo still exists in both Koreas.
Connect to present: The pattern of domestic crisis inviting foreign intervention that transforms local conflicts into international wars continues (Syria, Yemen). Korea's experience is not unique.
Ch'oe Sihyong's 'On Practicing Truth at Home' (treat servants as children, love animals, don't cut young trees) shows Tonghak wasn't just political - it offered a complete moral worldview.
